issues.title: those who worked on selective disclosure mechanisms with JSON
issues.author: bc-pi
issues.body:
https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt-00.html#name-acknowledgments

has anyone else worked on similar items for providing selective disclosure mechanisms in JSON? 

asking for a friend :) one who believes he's done some work on https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-oauth-selective-disclosure-jwt/

issues.title: sd_hash in issued CWT? issuer includes all possible disclosures?
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
currently the sd_hash claim in an SD-CWT is allowed when sent between an issuer and the holder. This is a claim which could not be verified by a verifier. I propose we remove it. If instead the Issuer is required to send salted claim disclosures for every digest in the payload (already proposed in PR #9 ), then the holder has another way of detecting tapering of the unprotected header. 

we also need confidentiality of the disclosures. the most common ways (ex: transport crypto, authenticated encryption of the entire SD-CWT) also provide additional integrity protection of the unprotected header between an issuer and a holder

issues.title: Support Decoy Digests
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
do we want to support decoy digests like SD-JWT does?

If so, I left a simple hook to do so in PR #9

issues.title: Can you have an SD-CWT with no blinded claims
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
is a zebra with no stripes still a zebra? 

likewise is it legal to have an SD-CWT with no blinded claims. shouldn't that just be a regular CWT?

It is easier to talk about what various roles have to do with this requirement. Is there a good reason to allow a CWT with `typ` "application/sd-cwt" that has no blinded claims?

Note that PR #9 currently assumes an SD-CWT needs at least one blinded claim.

issues.title: Optional vs. mandatory claims?
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
The standard claims (iss, sub, iat, exp, nbf, etc.) in CBOR Web Token largely reference the semantics of the corresponding claims in JSON Web Token, which makes all the claims optional. Which of the standard claims do we want to make mandatory or optional?

## Summary of standard claims in SD-CWT and SD-KBT

### issuer (iss / 1)
This is currently mandatory in the SD-CWT and optional in the SD-KBT.

### subject (sub / 2)
Currently mandatory in the SD-CWT and optional in the SD-KBT. 

### audience (aud / 3)
Currently optional in the SD-CWT and mandatory in the SD-KBT. Use of an SD-CWT with no audience, or a different/less specific audience than the SD-KBT, is a requirement for use inside MLS credentials.

### expiration (exp / 4)
This is currently optional in the SD-CWT, but I think it should be mandatory in both.

### not-before (nbf / 5)
Current optional in both.

### issued-at (iat / 6)
Currently mandatory in both. I think this is fine, but we could potentially relax this to require either iat or cti

### cwt token id (cti / 7)
Currently optional. See comment above.  

### key confirmation (cnf / 8)
Mandatory in SD-CWT. Not present in SD-KBT.

### client nonce (cnonce / 39)
Currently mandatory in SD-KBT and optional in SD-CWT.

### disclosures-hash (sd_hash / TBD3)
Currently mandatory in both. Recommend removing from SD-CWT as discussed in issue #10

### disclosures hash algorithm (sd_alg / TBD4)
Mandatory in SD-CWT. Not present in SD-KBT.

## Proposed changes
 - Add expiration (exp / 4) as mandatory in SD-CWT
 - Remove sd_hash from SD-CWT as discussed in #10

issues.title: Using "keys" in claim names for non-cryptographic keys is potentially confusing
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body:
Hi, Mike Jones pointed out that SD-CWT is using "keys" in claim names (ex: `redacted_keys`) in a way which is potentially confusing. We refer to cryptographic keys (ex: confirmation key—`cnf`) and CBOR map keys throughout the document.

The proposal is to rename `redacted_keys` to something else which makes it clear that it is a "map key" and not a cryptographic key. `redacted_elements` or `redacted_values` imply that only the values (and not the claim names) are included.

I propose:

`redacted_map_claims`

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
This naming needs to be consistent for arrays and maps.

- redacted_map_claims
- redacted_array_claim 

?

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> This naming needs to be consistent for arrays and maps.
> 
>     * redacted_map_claims
>     * redacted_array_claim

I'm not sure. The first is an array of claims that are each items in a map at the same level, and will have an integer key. The second is the map key of a single-element map which represents one item inside an array, and might be represented by the text strong "...".  

This still might be the best suggestion (or least bad). Let's see.

comments.author: mprorock

what about:

?

Mike, do you mean this?

redacted_claim_array_item

Thanks,

pulls.title: Move implementation status in accordance with BCP205
pulls.author: OR13
pulls.body: For inclusion in -01... now that the "no change" adoption call version is up: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt/00/

pulls.title: small fix to the CDDL
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body:
fix to full cddl and one instance of the same CDDL in the body of the draft

CDDL was not happy with:

```
? &(sd_claims: TBD1) ^ => [ +bstr .cbor salted ]
```

, so I replaced with:

```
? &(sd_claims: TBD1) ^ => bstr .cbor salted-array,
```

where `salted-array` is `salted-array = [ +bstr .cbor salted ]`

pulls.title: Make Abstract conform to IETF-required style
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body:
According to https://authors.ietf.org/required-content (Abstract section), the Abstract of an I-D or RFC needs to stand alone. It should not contain abbreviations or references.

Changes:
- Removed references from Abstract
- Expanded abbreviations in Abstract
- Added Updates: RFC8392 to metadata
- Introduced first references in Introduction
-

pulls.title: Add an Overview section which walks through the mechanism
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body:
- Added an Overview section which walks through the mechanism with plenty of examples.
- all salts use recommended length. digests are correct. (signatures still not yet)
- added an appendix with the keys for the Issuer and Holder
-

comments.author: mprorock
comments.body: @rohanmahy mind taking a look at conflicts post merge real quick?

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> @rohanmahy mind taking a look at conflicts post merge real quick?

resolved. The implementation section moved from an Appendix to a section in the main body of the draft.
All comments I received have been resolved (Thanks @selfissued ). @mprorock please go ahead and merge.

```suggestion
consists of standard CWT claims, the holder confirmation key, and five specific
custom claims. The payload is shown below in CBOR Extended Diagnostic
Notation (EDN) {{!I-D.ietf-cbor-edn-literals}}. Note that some of the CWT claim
map keys shown in the examples have been invented for this example and do not
have registered integer keys.
```

```suggestion
            /claim/  "postal_code",
```
"postal_code" is the registered JWT claim name, so you might as well use it in the example.

```suggestion
        "postal_code" : "94188"
```

```suggestion
            / redacted postal_code /
```

```suggestion
```

I don't think that including a hex CBOR representation enhances the readers' comprehension of the text.  The CDDL above does the job fine by itself.  I'd delete the hex CBOR.

pulls.title: Reoganize and partially rewrite the main normative sections
pulls.author: rohanmahy

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
sent to spice mailing list:
"A made three small technical changes, for which I will create issues after I take a break.

1) The text in this PR says that the Issuer has to send the Salted Disclosed Claims for every digest in an SD-CWT. If not the Issuer could issue claims that the Holder can never verify that could be embarrassing or false (like "Alice still likes the boy band of her youth", or "Rohan thinks the earth is flat"). (Update: Issue #10 )
2) I questioned if a CWT with no blinded claims can be an SD-CWT. My conclusion was no, so I changed the cardinality to at least 1 blinded claim. Of course you can disclose between zero and all of them. (Update: Issue #12 )
3) I left a hook to allow us to trivially add Decoy Digests (Update: Issue #11 )

I can change any of these things. Changing 1 and 3 are pretty trivial, and Changing 2 is still straightforward."

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
The acronym "EDN" is used without being expanded.  And there's no citation to its definition.

Please expand the acronym on first use *and* provide a citation.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> The acronym "EDN" is used without being expanded. And there's no citation to its definition.
> 
> Please expand the acronym on first use _and_ provide a citation.

Hi Mike,
There is an expansion of EDN in PR #8 which would come earlier in the document. I just added a reference there in [this commit](https://github.com/ietf-wg-spice/draft-ietf-spice-sd-cwt/pull/8/commits/f0b7e8ec750e5c21d34a2d59752f376751258aa8). I'll leave this comment open in case this PR is merged but #8 is not.

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
This PR is missing a description in the History appendix of the changes it is making in draft -01.  That's understandable under the circumstances, because the History section is missing from the draft!

Please create the History appendix at the end of the document, describing these changes in the -01 entry.  I suggest using this text:

# Document History

[[ to be removed by the RFC Editor before publication as an RFC ]]

-01

* <<<Change 1 description>>>
* <<<Change 2 description>>>
* <<<etc.>>>

-00

* Initial working group draft.

comments.body:
```suggestion
in CBOR and COSE. An SD-CWT MUST include the protected header parameter
`typ` {RFC9596} with the value `application/sd-cwt` in the SD-CWT.
```
"dict" isn't a CBOR or COSE term.

```suggestion
The Issuer MUST implement COSE_Sign1 using an appropriate asymmetric
```

```suggestion
The Issuer MUST generate a unique cryptographically random salt with at least
```
Why is "exp" optional?  It seems like it should be required.

I would change all instances of "redacted_keys" to "redacted_values".  It is unfortunate that CBOR chose to use the term "key" for the labels of objects, as it inevitably causes readers confusion between cryptographic keys and object keys.

Please let's reserve the term "key" for cryptographic keys.
I would suggest saying what about the unprotected header is different.  Help readers understand without having to look elsewhere in the spec.

RFC8392 is silent about if exp is required in a CWT. It refers to the definition in [Section 4.1.4 of RFC7519](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7519#section-4.1.4) which says `exp` is optional in a JWT.

```suggestion
SD-CWT to the Holder.) An SD-KBT is itself a type of CWT. The protected header of the SD-KBT
MUST include the `typ` header parameter with the value `application/sd-kbt`.
```

```suggestion
Profiles built on this specification are also encouraged to use more specific media types, as described in {{?RFC9596}}.
```

For what it's worth, *all* claims are optional in JWTs because they are expected to be profiled for particular use cases.  In our case, we may want to define the minimum required claims.

I thought that the "?" syntax above made "exp" optional.  Am I correct?  And similarly, the change above makes "aud" optional.  Is that what we want to do?

> 

```suggestion
in CBOR and COSE. An SD-CWT MUST include the protected header parameter
`typ` {{!RFC9596}} with the value "application/sd-cwt" in the SD-CWT.
```

```suggestion
replaced with a CBOR map containing only the special key "...".
```

> 

```suggestion
payload. The payload MUST also include a key confirmation element (`cnf`) {{!RFC8747}}
```

I have a legitimate use case for "aud" to be optional (use in MLS), but the "aud" would be required in the Key Binding Token.

For "exp" I cannot think of a use case where we want a never expiring SD-CWT, but I was hesitant to change the optionality and break someone else's use case.

> I would change all instances of "redacted_keys" to "redacted_values". It is unfortunate that CBOR chose to use the term "key" for the labels of objects, as it inevitably causes readers confusion between cryptographic keys and object keys.
> 
> Please let's reserve the term "key" for cryptographic keys.

"values" doesn't convey the difference between array items map elements. keys isn't really correct either.  How do folks feel about `redacted_elements`?

> 

```suggestion
Profiles built on this specification are also encouraged to use more specific media
types, as described in {{!RFC9596}}.
```
I meant `nbf` and `exp`. The current time is greater or equal to `nbf` and not more than `exp`. What comparison would you make with `iat`?
I'll take a stab at this tomorrow.
fixed

```suggestion
same syntax as an SD-CWT issued to a Holder, except for its unprotected header.
Since the unprotected header is not included in the signature, it will contain
all the Salted Disclosed Claims when sent from the Issuer to the Holder. By
comparison, the unprotected header will include a Key Binding Token and contain
none, some, or all of these Claims when sent from the Holder to the Verifier.
```

> I'll take a stab at this tomorrow.

How well does the proposed change (starting line 329) address your concern about explaining the unprotected header?
I created Issue #14 for this. I propose we resolve in this PR and incorporate the result of this conclusion in another PR.
I proposed `redacted_map_claims` in Issue #15 . Let's please merge this PR while these other issues get discussed.
Marking as resolved, to be addressed in Issue #14
Marking resolved. Captured in Issue #15
